bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to George A. Kellogg, March 27, 1941

div1.p: Kean criticizes the sketches for the Cornwell painting and discusses the anti-Reed sentiment in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to George A. Kellogg, March 27, 1941
div1.opener:
Dr. Hench
C
O
P
Y
2804 N. Street N.W.
Georgetown
Washington, D.C.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I have had your letter of March 4th stuck up on my
desk conspicuously ever since it came and have received two letters
from Dr. Hench and a carbon copy of Gen. Truby's letter about the
grouping of the actors in the Yellow Fever painting, but I have
hesitated to write to you because I cannot get up any enthusiasm
for such an artificial grouping as Dr. Hench proposes -- the
biting of Carroll by Lazear's mosquito was done in secret. There
were, I suspect no witnesses, although Sergeant Neate may have been
there. Reed was in the United States, and certainly Dr. Finlay was
not there.

Now, this sketch has just come from you, and it
looks as if they were all collected and posed for a photograph --
posing for photographs was a thing that Reed had such an aversion
to, that after his death the only picture that he had ever sat for
is that terrible one as a young man in the full dress uniform
which has been so much reproduced and has done his fine, noble
face so much injustice - Schuler's bust is a good likeness and it
should have been used for the 5¢ stamp and other representations of
him -- I hope that Mr. Cornwell will use it -- I really think that
Mr. Cornwell's first conception of Finlay giving Reed the mosquito
eggs in a dish in a Cuban patio is much more artistic and much
nearer to the historic varities. In my mind's eye comes up
always as the truly dramatic moment in a wonderful setting, the
interview between Major Reed and General Wood in the Palace in
Havana -- I described it 13 yrs. ago in an address at Reed's birth-
place, and it will save me from writing a long description of I
send you the address where you will find it - on page 300-301 -
of the excerpt.

But, of course, the artist could not bring in
Dr. Finlay or Reed's assistants, so this is not a suggestion for
Mr. Cornwell, unless he should want sometime a picture with just
those two in it. The importance of the occasion was that without
General Wood's approval, Reed could not have had any Camp Lazear,
nor could have continued these secret experiments or those with
infected bedding - for to prove the harmlessness of other sources
of infection, was of vast importance.

It was the demonstration that stopped all fumigations
and disinfections of inanimate objects - bedding, clothing, baggage, etc.
and taught us that contact with the yellow fever patient himself
was of no more danger than with a man with a broken leg.

Now, my dear Mr. Kellogg, I do not wish to oppose any plans
of my friends or to make converts, but just to tell you how I feell
about it, I have been for many years a proponent of Reed's fame
and I do not fear that it can now be harmed by giving to Dr. Finlay
the credit which is his due. Finlay made the discovery and
identified the variety of mosquito as far back as 1881 and
published it far and wide in the United States, as well as Cuba.
But, he could not convince anyone (except his assistant Dr. Delgado)
in 19 yrs. Then came Reed and in the words of Dr. Goldberger
of the Public Health Service, Reed converted a discredited theory
into an established doctrine.

The trouble with the Cubans is that they have been made
indignant by the failure of Americans to give proper credit to
Finlay as the discoverer and they go to the other extreme of claiming
everything for Finlay. I think that it is a squabble unworthy of
scientific men.

Dr. Hench is now in Cuba and I hope will win from the
Cuban authorities, the support and cooperation that is due his
energy and devotion to the investigation he has undertaken.
That so busy a man could have diverted so much time and labor
from his professional work, is extraordinary. I wish to help
him in every way in his study of the Cuban episode of 1900 - 1901
and to have not injected myself into the discussion of the
picture. But, I have no objection to having my feeling in the
matter known.

Please return my address when you have read it -- as it is
my only copy.

We were as pleased to get Robin's picture and your note.
She is a dear little girl and we were much struck by her pise and
ease of manner and her maturity of mind. She has real personality.

I hope you will excuse my long delay in writing. I have
no clerical help, as you see, and have had much to do, what with
income tax returns and other matters.

Mrs. Kean sends her regards to you and to Robin, and I
am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, (SIGNED) J. R. KEAN er
3/27/41
